data.title: W/NW/W:The Prime Minister is okay.
data.meta_description: On Friday, the prime minister of the Czech Republic, Mr. Vladimir Spidla, collapsed during a session of Parliment. data.text: On Friday, the prime minister of the Czech Republic, Mr. Vladimir Spidla, collapsed during a session of Parliment. He is having a tough time of it - classic aging population in a small country used to a high level of social services but no longer a tax base to support it sort of thing. End of last week, the Czechs finally had their EU Commissioner figured out (not an easy process) and everything was go speed racer - and then the appointed EU Commissioner chickened out and resigned before he had ever started. Thus, I think, the collapse of Mr. Spidla. On Sunday, my wife and I were walking through the park on our way back from brunch, when we saw this phalanx of photographers walking backwards, kneeling, shooting, walking backwards, etc. I thought, hey, maybe Mr. Spidla is out! Yes indeed, that is who it was. He was taking his official, "I am not dead yet" health of the Prime Minister and thus the country walk. He looked good, not great, but definitely not dead. Now he had maybe three body guards, each walking maybe thirty paces away from him. He was totally out in the open. While the park is right next door to his official residence, I still had the feeling I was seeing something extraordinarily democratic - extraordinary due to its rarity in any democracratic country these days. The idea of that an example of a free and open society would come from the Czech Republic, a country which has had such difficulty with openness even in the democratic era, is quite restorative I think, especially in light of the relatively recent deaths of Pim Fortuyn and Anna Lind. The politician in public may be a vanishing presence I am afraid, but for a moment, there he was. And his wife. And his dog.
